header.title: THE ARS NOVA, Book V of the Lemegeton
header.category: Western Esotericism, Grimoire Magic, Solomonic Magic

central_thesis: The Ars Nova functions as an auxiliary text within the Lemegeton tradition, primarily providing a series of divine and angelic invocations and prayers essential for the consecration of magical tools and the successful command and confinement of spirits in Solomonic operations (especially Goetic evocation), while also containing a unique and potent curse for the recovery of stolen goods.

structure_content.summary: This section discusses the provenance of Ars Nova from Sloane MS. 2731, arguing for a reversed page order from typical publications to create a logical sequence. It highlights the text's connection to the Goetia's tools (circle, triangle, hexagrams, pentagrams) and its content, which includes divine name lists, prayers, Hebrew characters, a prayer for spirit confinement, and the 'Mighty Oration' against thieves.

structure_content.chapter_title: The First Page of the Ars Nova
structure_content.summary: A collection of prayers and invocations directed at Almighty God and specific Holy Angels, often associated with Qabalistic spheres (Kether, Primum Mobile, Zodiac, Saturn, Mars), utilizing Divine Names (Eheie, Iehovah, Elohim, Sabaoth, etc.). These prayers seek divine and angelic assistance, command of spirits (air, water, fire, earth, hell), strengthening of undertakings, and defense from perils, likely to be spoken during the drawing or consecration of magical figures.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Explanation of the Two Triangles in the Parchment
structure_content.summary: This section provides invocations specifically for the Hexagram and Pentagrams. The invocations are commands to spirits to appear in human form, speak audibly, reveal treasures, and answer questions without defect, emphasizing the magician's authority derived from divine power (Alpha & Omega, Tetragrammaton).

A specific invocation for the Triangle of Art, commanding spirits to be subject to the magician and bound within the triangle. It leverages divine names (Tetragrammaton, Primeumaton) and the authority of Archangel Michael to ensure spirit confinement and control.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Second Page of the Ars Nova
structure_content.summary: This page contains sets of Hebrew characters with accompanying Latin names, followed by a prayer (invoking names like Jodgea, Rosen Emolack) intended for binding evil and aerial spirits, spirits of hidden treasure, and disturbers of mankind, confining them within a brass urn through divine power and the Archangel Michael.

A powerful curse utilizing potent Divine Names (Alpha & Omega, Jehovah, Emmanuel) and referencing numerous biblical miracles of divine power. It is explicitly directed at a thief, demanding the immediate return of stolen goods, with dire consequences if the command is not obeyed.

key_concepts.definition: A foundational grimoire compilation of Solomonic magic, also known as The Lesser Key of Solomon. Ars Nova is presented as Book V, providing supplementary material and invocations for its practices.

The first book of the Lemegeton, focused on the evocation and command of seventy-two infernal spirits. The Ars Nova's prayers and invocations are designed to complement and facilitate Goetic operations, particularly concerning the 'tools of the trade'.

Sacred appellations of God (e.g., Eheie, Iehovah, Elohim, Sabaoth, Tetragrammaton, Alpha & Omega, Emmanuel) inscribed on magical apparatus and invoked in prayers to solicit divine protection, power, and authority over spirits and phenomena.

Essential Solomonic ritualistic tools. The Circle provides protection for the magician, often inscribed with Divine Names (as per Ars Nova). The Triangle is where spirits are compelled to appear and are confined, with specific invocations (e.g., 'An Explanation Of Solomon's Triangle') binding them.

Geometrical figures used in Solomonic magic, typically drawn within or surrounding the Magical Circle, serving as protective symbols and foci for divine power. The Ars Nova provides invocations for spirits to appear related to these figures.
A unique and potent curse within the Ars Nova, invoked through the authority of numerous divine names and biblical miracles, specifically aimed at compelling a thief to return stolen goods.

This specific compendium of prayers, invocations, and divine names, intended for consecration, angelic assistance, spirit command, and a specialized curse. It is often considered an appendix or supplementary material to the more famous Goetia.

practical_system.description: The Ars Nova outlines a system of divine and angelic invocation designed to support ceremonial magic, primarily Goetic operations. It focuses on establishing spiritual authority, consecrating the workspace and implements, securing divine and angelic aid, and explicitly commanding and confining spirits. The system relies heavily on the power of specific Divine Names and the hierarchy of celestial beings. Additionally, it contains a specialized ritual for employing divine authority to compel the return of stolen property.
tools: Magickal Circle of Art (to be inscribed with Divine Names from Ars Nova, providing protection)
Magickal Triangle (for spirit appearance and confinement, consecrated with specific invocations)
Hexagrams (to be inscribed with Divine Names, potentially for commanding spirits)
Pentagrams (to be inscribed with Divine Names, potentially for commanding spirits)
Brass Urn/Vessel (for confining evil and aerial spirits, as mentioned in the prayers)
rituals: Daily or preparatory prayers/invocations to God and associated Angels (e.g., Kether, Primum Mobile, Zodiac, Saturn, Mars) for assistance, strength, and protection.
Invocations to be spoken while drawing or consecrating the Magical Circle, Hexagrams, and Pentagrams, embedding them with Divine Names and power.
Specific commands to spirits (of various regions and elements) to appear in human shape, speak, reveal hidden treasures, and answer questions, to be performed within the Magical Circle.
Invocations for binding spirits within the Triangle of Art, utilizing Divine Names (Tetragrammaton, Primeumaton) and the authority of Archangel Michael.
A specialized prayer for confining evil and aerial spirits into a brass urn, invoking powerful divine names and the Archangel Michael.
The 'Mighty Oration': A curse ritual employing numerous potent Divine Names and biblical references to compel a thief to immediately return stolen goods.

relevant_quotes.text: Most of the text of Ars Nova clearly relates to the first book of the Lemegeton, the Goetia, and the “tools of the trade” described therein: the magickal circle and triangle, the hexagrams within the circle and the pentagrams surrounding it.
Let thy Holy Angels be commanded to assist me at this time and at all times.
That I may command all spirits of air, water, fire, earth, and hell: So that it may tend unto Thy glory and unto the good of man.

I command thee, thou Spirit, of whatsoever region thou art, to come unto this circle: And appear in human shape: And speak unto us audibly in our mother-tongue: (or Bellony) And show, and discover unto us all treasure that thou knowest of, or that is in thy keeping, and deliver it unto us quietly: And answer all such questions as we may demand without any defect now at this time.
Let all spirits be subject unto us, and let the Spirit be bound in this triangle, that disturbs this place: By Thy Holy Angel Michael, until I shall discharge him.

thou thief return immediately & restore the goods again which thou hast stolen away, therefore in & by the names of the Almighty God before rehearsed I charge thee, thou thief to restore the goods again immediately or else the wrath of God may fall upon thee & force thee to come immediately. Amen.

critical_analysis.relevance: The Ars Nova serves as a crucial, albeit often overlooked, appendix to the Lemegeton, particularly in its practical application alongside the Goetia. It elucidates the preparatory and protective divine invocations intended to fortify the magician's authority, consecrate ritual spaces and tools, and ensure angelic assistance. Its comprehensive listing of divine names linked to various spheres and its explicit instructions for commanding and binding spirits within the magical schema provide invaluable context for Solomonic operations. The inclusion of the 'Mighty Oration' against thieves is a rare and striking example of pragmatic grimoire magic extending beyond spirit evocation to address mundane concerns, showcasing the multifaceted utility of such texts in historical practice.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is intended for serious practitioners and academic researchers of Solomonic ceremonial magic, particularly those studying the Lemegeton/Goetia. It provides essential supplementary invocations and prayers for conducting effective and safe spirit evocations, consecrating magical apparatus, and understanding the theological underpinnings of grimoire magic. It is also relevant for those interested in the historical application of magical curses for practical, everyday concerns.
